ECU's Riley a contender for UK coordinator job

East Carolina's Lincoln Riley a contender for UK football's offensive coordinator opening

ECU's Riley a contender for UK coordinator job

Kyle Tucker, ktucker@courier-journal.com 8:39 p.m. EST December 4, 2014

In this Wednesday, April 11, 2012 photo, East Carolina offensive coordinator for quarterback Lincoln Riley coaches during football practice in Greenville, N.C. With Dominique Davis gone, East Carolina has an open race for its starting quarterback job. (AP Photo/Gerry Broome)(Photo: Gerry Broome, ASSOCIATED PRESS)

7 CONNECT 45 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Tune into ESPN right now to see a candidate for Kentucky's open offensive coordinator job as East Carolina hosts Central Florida. The Pirates' 31-year-old coordinator, Lincoln Riley, is a rising star and Wildcats head coach Mark Stoops intends to speak to Riley about the vacancy sometime after this game, according to a source familiar with the situation.

Riley has expressed interest in the position, the source said, but wanted to get through ECU's regular-season finale tonight. He would provide continuity for Kentucky's offense as he is another disciple of the "Air Raid" that Neal Brown – introduced this week as Troy's head coach – installed the last two seasons in Lexington.

MORE: Exit Interview: Neal Brown's parting thoughts

MORE: UK's Neal Brown announced as Troy head coach

Riley, who is the Pirates' assistant head coach, OC and quarterbacks coach, is a Texas Tech alum. He spent seven total seasons with the Red Raiders' program as a walk-on quarterback, student assistant, graduate assistant and finally full-time assistant. He was Mike Leach's wide receivers coach from 2007-09. His five seasons as ECU's offensive coordinator hold the top five spots in the school's record book for passing yardage.

Under Riley, the Pirates ranked top-20 nationally in passing four times in five years, top-25 in total offense three times and top-15 in scoring three times. They rank third in the country in both passing and total offense this season and entered tonight averaging 543.8 yards and 37.8 points per game.

He has helped East Carolina (8-3) do what the Cats are trying to: light up the scoreboard against teams with superior talent. The Pirates have beaten Power 5 opponents North Carolina (twice), N.C. State and Virginia Tech in the last two seasons. They hung 789 yards and 70 points on the Tar Heels this fall.

ECU quarterback Shane Carden set a new school record with 11,085 (and counting) total career yards, while receiver Justin Hardy broke the NCAA's all-time receptions record with 349 catches for 4,241 yards. Kentucky's current players would no doubt be excited to play for the guy whose offense produced those numbers.

Troy press conference announcing hiring of Brown.

Riley is not the only candidate Stoops will consider. Former Nebraska coordinator Tim Beck, Cincinnati coordinator Eddie Gran, former Duke and Florida coordinator Kurt Roper and Murray State head coach Chris Hatcher are other rumored candidates, but Riley is the only name a source close to the situation has confirmed.

One report that Beck had emerged as a leading candidate is "completely false," said the source, who also previously indicated Stoops has "no intention" of speaking to his former FSU colleague and current Miami coordinator James Coley about the opening. UK posted the job on Monday and could not officially make a hire until next week.

* For instant updates on the Wildcats, follow me on Twitter @KyleTucker_CJ. Email me at ktucker@courier-journal.com.
